comment.author: 69772308@N05
comment._content:
Nearest census link is 1901 Marcus Brown, born 1893 Holborn. Father Bernard Bronw, Mother Rose Brown, 2 sons 1 daughter living at  38, Millman Street, St Andrew Holborn Above The Bars And St George The Martyr County: London 
May not be correct.

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
Somewhat strange that his rank is recorded as Private and yet the photograph shows his tunic with Corporal’s stripes [or is it Lance Sergeant for the Guards regiments? I can never remember]. 
I guess that we will never know when the photograph was taken but for him to have enlisted in September 1914 – die in September the following year and have attained the rank of Corporal was quite meteoric.
Based on gill_a1’s census findings, here is the location of the 1901 family home in Millman Street, WC1.  Number 38 was on the east side of the street. I have determined the location using the 1915 Post Office Street Directory for London. The public house at the junction of Guilford Street and Millman Street was No.72 so counting back I have determined that No.38 is the property marked in red. The east side of the street has been completely rebuilt [not, I think, as a result of WW2 bomb damage] and nothing of the original remains. [Update 19/12/11 The premises were demilished due to subsidence sometime after 1950]
Click on the photo for a large version.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/liits/6395990827/in/photostream]

comment.author: 38811045@N04
comment._content:
Note the skill-at-arms signalling badge on his left forearm.  

Are we 100% sure this is a photo from 1914/1915?  It looks earlier than that to me. Can a uniform expert please confirm.  Is this walking-out dress?

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38811045@N04] Yes this is a walking-out uniform.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content:
Re. the queries about Pte Brown's uniform, the IWM uniforms expert has provided the following information:

This soldier is a corporal serving with a line infantry regiment, post 1905.  Whilst his tunic is of the type introduced in 1902 with pointed cuffs, replacing the earlier 'Jam Pot' straight cut types, the headdress known as the Forage Cap seen here came into service in 1905.  A qualified signaller (he wears crossed flags at his lower left cuff), his cap badge is indistinct.  The collar badge however does resemble the type worn by The South Staffordshire Regiment, or may even be of The Prince Of Wales' North Staffordshire Regiment.  Both of the above regiments wore white facings, as does Pte Brown.

comment.author: 44243665@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/69772308@N05] 
I am sure that this person did not serve in the coldstream guards and is not a private there are no privates in the gurds the rank is guardsman he has two cheverons on his arm denoting that he is a corpral and the tunic of a guardsman in the coldstream guards the buttons go in groups of two's, three buttons scots, four buttons is welsh, and five being irish, with the grenadier being single
As i served with the scots guards i have some knowledge and i cannot recall seeing the uniform looking like that if anything he would have had to of been in the grenadiers i hope this helps clear up some misstakes please do not take this as a criticism

comment.author: 31324280@N02
comment._content: W-o-a-E looks to have a point. It does not seem to be a guards uniform. Secondly, the cap badge looks like the Essex Volunteer Regiment. See: www.militarybadges.org.uk/badges/infan12.htm That regiment was, as far as I can see, a home duties regiment, and its members were not eligible for overseas service. So is this Private Mark Brown, but his regiment is given wrongly, or another chap entirely? Or was he a transferee from the Essex Volunteers to the Coldstream Guards?

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: Thanks for all the comments and useful bits of information. We'll leave the information as it stands, for now, until it is possible to say for certain what his rank and regiment were. More investigation needed!

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content: There is the possibility that the uniform did not belong to the chap in the photo and that it belonged to the photographer. I have a studio photograph of my grandparents [mother’s parents] taken in Leeds some time just after they were married, Grandma has so many ostrich feathers that she looks like an exotic dancer and Granddad is wearing a safari suit with a pith helmet! [all from the photographers costume box].
